newsitem.title: USA: FCC approves Bell Atlantic-NYNEX merger.
newsitem.headline: FCC approves Bell Atlantic-NYNEX merger.

text.p: The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday approved the $23 billion merger of Bell Atlantic Corp. and Nynex Corp., sweeping away the last hurdle to creation of the nation's No. 2 telephone company.
However, the FCC attached a number of conditions to the deal, which will form the nation's largest local carrier and the second-biggest communications company after long-distance giant AT&T Corp.

The conditions, which were expected, are meant to ensure the two Baby Bells open their 13-state phone market in the Northeast to rivals wanting to offer local phone service. The carriers agreed to many of them last month, paving the way for FCC approval.

The deal was first announced in April 1996. The new Bell Atlantic will serve an area stretching from Maine to Virginia that encompasses 39 million phone lines and will rank 23rd on Fortune magazine's list of the 500 largest U.S. corporations.
The companies are expected to close the deal shortly. Together, they will have combined assets of more than $50 billion and rank as the nation's largest local phone company.

They will have more than 140,000 employees worldwide offering business and residential customers local, wireless and Internet services. The new company is expected soon to seek approval to offer long-distance calling to its customers.
